instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello everybody :-)

I'm currently working on a MBP (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) with some corrosion around <CAPACITOR>C6406</CAPACITOR> with pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
It is taking 20V and pulsing 15mA to 22mA.

I don't see any obvios liquid damage on <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, but I think this could cause the pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>? It's pretty close to <CAPACITOR>C6406</CAPACITOR> and could be damaged too?

I am a bit cautious since it is a very new device - so I prefer to ask here first :) 
Best regars

Lucas

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Which schematic used in the repair process?

threads.message: I have the correct schematic - just missing boardview. But there is a illustration of the components in the schematic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Steady 20V at USB input?

Check for short on all big coils.
Be sure all solders and traces around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes I'm getting steady 20V at USB input (according to my USB-C amp-meter).

Resistance to Ground on the big coils:
L7270: 4.2 Ω,
L7210: 0.6 Ω, 
L7220: 0.6 Ω,
L7410: 0.8 Ω 
L7420: 0.8 Ω,
L7702: 41.5 Ω,
L8102: 130.5 Ω,
L8100: 0.295 kΩ,
L7030: 365 kΩ,
L7690: 1.9 kΩ,
L7670: 23 Ω,
L8410: 1.11 MΩ,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"L7210: 0.6 Ω, 
L7220: 0.6 Ω,
L7410: 0.8 Ω 
L7420: 0.8 Ω"
Looks like shorted CPU.
To be sure, lift all these coil one side and see where the shorts remain.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
The shorts remain on the CPU (PPVCC/GT) side (pin 2) on all of the 4 coils.
Just injected 1.5V on pin 2 of coil L7210 - the CPU took 3 apms, getting warm but not as hot (especially not locally hot) like the other CPU shorts occured on other boards i had for repair in the last months.

I'm still struggling in rating if a resistance of the CPU core is good or not(if it's not 0 or 0.1 Ω :D)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
The resistance should be bit higher than 1 ohm.
If you have 0.6 ohm, multimeter leads have 0.3 ohm probably.
So CPU itself remains with 0.3 ohm...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hmm okay :-( Maybe just don't want to admit that it's another dead CPU :D That was the diagnosis of my last 5 boards.
Sould the pulsing of the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> stop with removed coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I just measured the resistance of the CPU a friends Macbook Pro from 2019. Odlly he had nearly the same CPU resistance (0.9 Ω and 0.8 Ω) on the coils. So maybe there is still some hope for the MBP?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: As a reminder resistance to ground must be measured when board/CPU is dead cold and all power drained from it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - pulsing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That's what I did :-) Battery disconnected, board was completely cold, left the probes very long for the measurement to be sure it is completely discharged :-)
